Contents Basic Panel Docked Components Closing

Ext.panel.Panel

The Panel class is one of the more versatile and foundational elements of the Ext JS component library. Panels may be used as stand alone containers of HTML, containers for child items, or participate in a larger layout as a child item itself. Panels are highly configurable with options for a title bar (header), framing borders, collapsing or closing, and the docking of other components to the sides of the Panel.
Additionally, the Panel class provides the foundation for many of the other components in the framework such as Form Panels, Tab Panels, Menus, Grids, Trees, and Windows.

In its simplest form, a Panel may be used to display HTML content in the panel body.

Ext.create({
    xtype: 'panel',
    renderTo: Ext.getBody(),
    width: 200,
    height: 200,
    html: 'Hello World!'    // HTML displayed in the panel body
});

Or serve as a container of child items.

Ext.create({
    xtype: 'panel',
    renderTo: Ext.getBody(),
    width: 200,
    height: 200,
    layout: 'anchor',
    // a single child component managed by an anchor layout
    items: [{
        xtype: 'component',
        html: 'Hello World!'
    }]
});

Note: If a Panel is solely used to display HTML a simple Component or Widget will be the better choice. If used only to hold other child items then a Container will be the better choice. While panels aren’t categorically expensive components in terms of DOM and memory weight, in this instance it’s not the most economical choice.

Basic Panel

Panels may be craete with a title bar (header) for added presentation including title text.

Ext.create({
    xtype: 'panel',
    renderTo: Ext.getBody(),
    width: 200,
    height: 200,
    title: 'Hello',     // a title bar is added automatically when a title is set
    bodyPadding: 20,    // provides the panel content with additional whitespace
    html: 'World!'
});

In the example so far, the Panel shows up plain with no border (often the best choice when the panel is the child item of a parent container). However, Panels may be configured with the frame option to give it a more stand-alone appearance. The title bar may also be positioned on any side of the Panel body.

Ext.create({
    xtype: 'panel',
    renderTo: Ext.getBody(),
    width: 200,
    height: 200,
    title: 'Hello!',
    bodyPadding: 20,
    html: 'World,',
    frame: true,    // adds a framing border (and rounded corners on some themes)
    margin: 20,     // offsets the panel from its surroundings
    headerPosition: 'bottom'    // may also be left or right
});

Panels may be configured as collapsible to allow the body of the panel to be collapsed into the header. It may also be configured as closable which allows users to click the close icon resulting in either the Panel being hidden or destroyed depending on the value of the closeAction config option. In addition to the title text, the header bar is where the collapse, close, or any other header tools are located.

Ext.create({
    xtype: 'panel',
    renderTo: Ext.getBody(),
    width: 200,
    height: 200,
    title: 'Hello',
    bodyPadding: 20,
    html: 'World!',
    frame: true,
    margin: 20,
    collapsible: true,  // collapses the panel body into the header
    // the panel is now closable which hides or destroys the panel 
    // when the close tool is clicked
    closable: true,
    // tools added to the panel will show up in the panel header
    tools: [{
        type: 'gear'
    }]
});

You can easily center the Panel’s title using the titleAlign config. Using the titleAlign config along with the header config (including the header class’s itemPosition config option) you can explicitly arrange the elements of the Panel header.

Ext.create({
    xtype: 'panel',
    renderTo: Ext.getBody(),
    width: 400,
    height: 200,
    title: 'Hello World!',
    frame: true,
    margin: 20,
    collapsible: true,
    titleAlign: 'center',   // may be left, center, or right
    // use the header config for greater control over the header layout
    header: {
        // by specifying the header tools in the header config you can 
        // take advantage of the itemPosition option to indicate where
        // in the header you want the header tools (items) to be displayed
        itemPosition: 0,
        items: [{
            type: 'gear'
        }]
    }
});

Icons may be used in the Panel header as well. The icon and iconCls configs allow you set the icon using an image asset or CSS class. With the Triton theme (Ext JS 6+ only) you may even use icons from the Font Awesome font icon library.

Ext.create({
    xtype: 'panel',
    renderTo: Ext.getBody(),
    width: 200,
    height: 200,
    title: 'Hello',
    bodyPadding: 20,
    html: 'World!',
    frame: true,
    margin: 20,
    iconCls: 'x-fa fa-thumbs-o-up'
});

Docked Components

Panels descend from the Container class and may use all of the container layouts available to manage their child items. Panels also include a helpful layout option above and beyond what the generic Container class, the option to dock a component (or multiple components) on the Panel’s sides. Commonly the docked item is a Toolbar, though it could be any component you need to dock. Panels have four convenience config options for adding docked toolbars: tbar, bbar, lbar, and rbar that dock a toolbar on the top, bottom, left, and right sides respectively.

Ext.create({
    xtype: 'panel',
    renderTo: Ext.getBody(),
    width: 200,
    height: 200,
    title: 'Terms and Conditions',
    bodyPadding: 20,
    html: 'Click "Agree" to accept the Terms and Conditions',
    frame: true,
    margin: 20,
    // docks a toolbar to the bottom edge of the panel
    bbar: [{
        text: 'Agree'
    }]
});

The previous example docked a toolbar at the bottom of the panel with a single “Agree” button. There is an additional convenience configs provided by the Panel class for docking a toolbar to the bottom edge that includes additional styling for both the docked toolbar and any buttons it owns: fbar. With the fbar config the toolbar items will be aligned to the right by default instead of the left unless you set buttonAlign to “left” or specify “start” as the pack config option of the toolbar’s layout.

Note: The buttons config may also be used in place of the fbar config. The outcome of both configs is identical.

Ext.create({
    xtype: 'panel',
    renderTo: Ext.getBody(),
    width: 200,
    height: 200,
    title: 'Terms and Conditions',
    bodyPadding: 20,
    html: 'Click "Agree" to accept the Terms and Conditions',
    frame: true,
    margin: 20,
    // docks a toolbar to the bottom edge of the panel and sets the
    // "footer" ui config of the toolbar resulting in additional styling
    // on the docked toolbar and its buttons
    fbar: [{
        text: 'Agree'
    }],
    buttonAlign: 'left' // set as "left" to left-align all child items
});

Panels can dock toolbars or any other component using the dockedItems config. In the following example we’ll dock a toolbar to the left of the panel and a button on the bottom.

Ext.create({
    xtype: 'panel',
    renderTo: Ext.getBody(),
    width: 300,
    height: 200,
    title: 'Terms and Conditions',
    bodyPadding: 20,
    html: 'Click "Agree" to accept the Terms and Conditions',
    frame: true,
    margin: 20,
    // any number of components may be docked within a panel using the
    // dockedItems config option
    dockedItems: [{
        xtype: 'toolbar',
        dock: 'left',   // the component will dock to the 'top' unless specified
        items: [{
            text: 'Nav Btn'
        }]
    }, {
        xtype: 'toolbar',
        dock: 'left',
        ui: 'footer',   // here we've added footer styling to a left toolbar
        items: [{
            text: 'Info'
        }]
    }, {
        xtype: 'button',
        dock: 'bottom',
        text: 'Agree',
        margin: 4
    }]
});

Closing

Panel’s versatility and utility ensure it will be used over and over in your applications. In addition to being used directly, panels play an important role in a number of the the framework’s other components and layouts. Panels will be used when organizing views in an accordion layout. It’s also the component used when adding tabs to a tab panel as well as the go-to view for most views configured with the popular border layout. You can even configure the panel as floating. Though for more info on the use of floating panels you’ll likely want to delve into the window component guide.
The window class is a dedicated floating panel class with its own list of handy attributes your’e sure to make good use of in your own applications.

Last updated
April 1, 2016
